body:
Problem:  Statusline component of diagnostics allows only the default
          format "sign:count".

Solution: Extend vim.diagnostic.Opts.Status to allow a custom
          formatting function.

comment_data.body:
Should the format function be responsible for adding highlights itself (for more customization)?

Otherwise, it seems like maybe just having a `separator` option would be cleaner (default `:`)

comment_data.body:
I thought about it, but having separator would limit the users' ability to say change the order of elements to something like `3 W`. So instead of having more parameters I think it's better to have 1 but flexible.

As for the highlight, I can see having custom highlight groups for status line. But rather than do it in format, I think of `highlight_groups` field in `vim.diagnostic.Opts.Status`, just like `numhl` and `linehl` for Signs.
If done in the format func, users will have to deal with the statusline syntax, don't think we need that. Also will be more in line with other diagnostic opts.

I don't mind adding it, just wasn't sure whether should be done in the same PR.

comment_data.body:
Hmm, so it would require to update `vim.diagnostic.count` to return 0 instead of of `nil` for missing diagnostic types.

It was my initial idea to take severity as an argument, but I don't see it playing well with the recently added `vim.diagnostic.Opts.Status.text` option, in a way that currently `status()` uses `text` option or the default icons (E, W, I, H.)
Passing just severity and count would make users to reimplement the default values.

Also for the filtering I think it's better to add `vim.diagnostic.Opts.Status.severity` option (just like for `vim.diagnostic.Opts.Float` for example) to filter by severity.

But I think it's a great idea to allow the format function to return `nil` to display 0 values.

So I'm thinking of the default format function like
```lua
local function default_status_format(sign, count)
  return count == 0 and nil or ('%s:%s'):format(sign, count)
end
```

and then
```lua
local severities = {}
for severity, count in pairs(counts) do
  local value = value_format(signs[severity], count)
  if value then
    table.insert(severities, ('%%#%s#%s'):format(hl_map[severity], value))
  end
end
return table.concat(severities, ' ')
```

comment_regular_data.body:
To sum it up, this is what I see as the improvement plan:
- adding custom built-in highlight groups
- add `vim.diagnostic.Opts.Status.severity` as severity filter, just like Float or Signs handle it
- add `vim.diagnostic.Opts.Status.separator` to customize how different severity components are joined (currently with a space) like "E:3 W:1"
- update format function signature to be able to return `nil` to exclude severity.

I'm still not certain when it comes to the format function signature as taking sign and count makes it more integrated with other settings.
Maybe when fetching config, I should copy it, then override signs in that copy an pass severity + count + config to the format function so that signs can be resolved safely?

@ribru17 please share your opinion and let me know whether any/all of the above should be implemented in this PR.

Thanks!

do we still need `diagnostic.config.status` table, or could we just replace it with  `diagnostic.config.format` function (which could also take some sort of `kind:'sign'|'status'` parameter)? why do we need both?

@justinmk if I have a vote here, I think having separate set of configuration options for status line is more in line with the rest of diagnostic configuration (there already are virtual_text, virtual_line, float, etc.)

Also signs are conceptually different from status line in a way that sign is pretty much a single element and all you need to be able to control is:
1) what is show (filter by severity + configure text)
2) how it is shown - highlight group.

Status line on the other hand how a counter associated with each sign and that's where different combinations come. So making a single function will likely make it overloaded. So I personally think it's better to have configuration separate.
I am not suggesting to remove `sign`, I am asking why `status` needs to be a table with numerous options instead of e.g. `status:fun()`.

Sorry, might be some misunderstanding. I never suggested removing signs, only meant that having one function to handle both signs and status line isn't the best fit here.

Having `status` as a function in a config is fine imo. I can do it, though should I do it right away or wait for some sort of green light?
@MariaSolOs is this something like you had in mind?
@sagg0t no need to mark this as breaking. The entire feature is new and so we're allowed to break stuff at this stage.
